questions.text: A physician observed the following finding in a small child who came for an eye exam. This finding is associated with which of the following conditions?  (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hyperopia

 

Esotropia (convergent squint) is commonly seen in children with hyperopia (also known as hypermetropia).

 

Accommodative esotropia:

 

It occurs due to overaction of convergence associated with accommodation reflex. It is of three types:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myopia (Short-sightedness):

  • Esotropia: Less common in myopic children.
  • Refractive Error: Light focuses in front of the retina.
  • Symptoms: Difficulty seeing distant objects clearly.

 

Option B. Astigmatism:

  • Effect on Squint: Can cause both esotropia and exotropia depending on the axis and severity of astigmatism.
  • Refractive Error: Light is focused at multiple points due to an irregular corneal shape.
  • Symptoms: Blurred or distorted vision at all distances.

 

Option D. Emmetropia (Normal Vision):

  • Esotropia: Rarely associated.
  • Refractive Error: No significant refractive error; light focuses correctly on the retina.
  • Symptoms: Normal vision without the need for corrective lenses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperopia is commonly associated with accommodative esotropia in children, where the effort to focus on near objects results in excessive convergence and inward deviation of the eyes. Corrective lenses help to reduce the accommodative effort, thereby alleviating the esotropia.

questions.text: A child presented with bilateral cataracts, patent ductus arteriosus, and sensorineural hearing loss. What can be the most probable diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Congenital Rubella

 

Congenital Rubella Syndrome (CRS) is classically associated with a triad remembered as "CHD":

  • Cataracts (bilateral)
  • Heart disease (particularly patent ductus arteriosus)
  • Deafness (sensorineural hearing loss)

 

This triad occurs due to the rubella virus's teratogenic effects during early pregnancy, particularly during the first trimester when organogenesis is occurring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Congenital Toxoplasmosis: Presents with a different triad ("C3"): Chorioretinitis, intracranial Calcifications, and hydrocephalus (Cephalus). It does not typically cause cataracts or cardiac defects.

 

Option B. Congenital Syphilis: Features the "INH" triad: Interstitial keratitis, Neurosensory deafness, and Hutchinson's teeth. While it can cause hearing loss, it doesn't typically present with cataracts or cardiac defects.

 

Option D. Neisseria gonorrhea: Primarily causes ophthalmia neonatorum (conjunctivitis) in newborns. It does not cause congenital malformations or systemic manifestations.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Congenital Rubella Syndrome is characterized by the "CHD" triad of Cataracts, Heart disease (PDA), and Deafness, distinguishing it from other TORCH infections.

questions.text: Which of the following lipid storage disorder presents with Cherry Red Spot in Macula? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tay Sach's disease

 

Tay Sachs disease is a lipid storage disorder that characteristically presents with a cherry-red spot in the macula. This appearance is due to the accumulation of gangliosides in the retinal ganglion cells, causing the macula to appear pale and contrasting with the normal red color of the fovea, creating the cherry-red spot appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gaucher's disease: While it may cause pseudo cherry-red spot and not a true cherry-red spot in ophthalmology.

 

Option C. Krabbe's disease: This is a leukodystrophy that primarily affects the nervous system but does not typically cause a cherry-red spot in the macula.

 

Option D. Fabry's disease: While this condition can affect the eyes, it typically causes corneal verticillata (corneal whorls) rather than a cherry-red spot in the macula.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cherry-red spot in the macula is a characteristic finding in several lipid storage disorders, with Tay Sachs disease being the most notable.

 

The mnemonic "BeE STING" can be helpful in remembering causes of cherry-red spot: Berlin's Edema, Sclerosis, Tay-Sachs, Ischemia (CRAO), Niemann-Pick, and GM1 Gangliosidosis.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presented with a white pupillary reflex for which enucleation was done. The histopathological examination of the specimen showed Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Retinoblastoma

 

The most likely diagnosis with a histopathological finding of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes in a 7-year-old child with a whitish pupillary reflex is retinoblastoma. Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes refer to an arrangement of columnar cells around a central lumen, which is highly characteristic of retinoblastoma.

 

 

 

  • Retinoblastoma is a malignant proliferation of immature retinal neural cells and is the most common intraocular malignancy in children.
  • It is associated with mutations in the RB1 gene at chromosome 13q14.
  • It is a tumour of a group called small round blue cell tumours because the immature retinal neural cells are seen as small round cells with large nuclei.
  • Most common presentation is leukocoria.
  • 2nd most common symptom is squint.
  • Clinical Features:

 

i). Quiescent stage:

  • Characterized by Leukocoria which is also known as Amaurotic cat’s eye appearance, convergent squint, defective vision and nystagmus (seen in bilateral cases).
  • Ophthalmoscopically, endophytic retinoblastoma gives “cottage cheese appearance” whereas exophytic tumor present as exudative retinal detachment.

 

ii). Glaucomatous stage:

  • Presents as severe pain, redness and watering. It may also result in hyphemia or pseudo hypopyon (contains tumor cells).

 

iii). Extraocular extension:

  • Globe burst through sclera near limbus and presents as marked proptosis.

 

iv). Distant metastasis:

  • Metastasis of retinoblastoma spread to
  • Optic nerve via direct extension
  • Pre-auricular lymph nodes via lymphatics
  • Cranial bones via blood
  • Microscopy – Flexner-Winter Steiner rosettes.
  • Treatment:
  • Enucleation
  • Chemotherapy→ intra-arterial chemo – melphalan in ophthalmic artery is very successful.
  • VEC is very successful:
  • V – Vincristine
  • E – Etoposide
  • C – Carboplatin

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Medulloblastoma: A malignant brain tumor located in the posterior fossa, not associated with intraocular findings or leukocoria.

 

Option C. Rhabdomyosarcoma: A soft tissue sarcoma affecting muscles, often presenting as a mass in the orbit but not causing leukocoria or associated with Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes.

 

Option D. Astrocytoma: A tumor of the central nervous system (glial origin), which does not occur intraocularly and is not linked with Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes are a hallmark of retinoblastoma, indicating a malignant proliferation of immature retinal neural cells. This specific histopathological finding is crucial for diagnosing retinoblastoma, especially in children presenting with leukocoria.

 

Different rosettes seen in retinoblastoma:
 

1. True rosette -FLEXNER-WINTERSTEINER ROSETTE

  • This is specific for RB - hallmark of RB
  • It consists of tumor cells surrounding a central lumen that contains cytoplasmic extensions from the tumor cells, which have well-differentiated features suggestive of primitive photoreceptor cells.

 

2. HOMER-WRIGHT ROSETTE is a non-specific rosette seen in any of the primitive neuroectodermal tumors. Tumor cells surround a central region containing neutrophil.

 

3. FLUERETTE is pseudo rosette because the central structure is not a part of the tumor and it consists of tumor cells around a blood vessel.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy was brought with the complaints of protrusion of the right eye with no h/o fever. CT Scan showed a well-defined mass in the orbit with an irregular border and adjacent bony destruction. Biopsy showed small, round cells which were positive for Desmin in Immunohistochemistry. What is the probable diagnosis? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rhabdomyosarcoma  

 

Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical and histological findings. It is a malignant tumor derived from skeletal muscle and commonly presents in the pediatric population as a rapidly enlarging orbital mass, often causing displacement of the eye (proptosis). The biopsy findings of small, round cells positive for Desmin, a muscle-specific intermediate filament, support the diagnosis. The location and aggressive nature of the tumor, indicated by bony destruction, are characteristic of rhabdomyosarcoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retinoblastoma: This is a common malignant intraocular tumor of childhood but would not typically present with bony destruction or be positive for Desmin.

 

Option B. Cavernous Hemangioma: This is a benign vascular tumor seen in adults and is not associated with rapid progression or positive Desmin staining.

 

Option C. Orbital Cellulitis: This infection would present with signs of inflammation and fever, which are not described in the scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the instrument.(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lim’s forceps


Lim's forceps are designed for ophthalmic procedures as well. They are used to hold and stabilize the eye during surgery, particularly during corneal suturing. They have a platform-like, non-toothed tip to hold the delicate eye tissue without causing damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. McPherson forceps: McPherson forceps are typically very delicate instruments used in ophthalmic surgery, especially in procedures involving the cornea and the lens, such as cataract surgery. They have very fine tips for precise manipulation of delicate eye tissues.

 

Option C. Artery forceps: Artery forceps, also known as hemostats, are used in various types of surgeries to grasp and clamp blood vessels to prevent bleeding. They are usually not used in ophthalmic surgeries due to their size and the nature of their design, which is intended to handle larger structures than those found within the eye.

 

Option D. SR (Suture Removal) holding forceps: SR holding forceps are designed for the removal of sutures. They have a small, notched tip at one end to grab and hold the suture for easier removal. They are generally not delicate enough for holding eye tissues during ophthalmic surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lim’s forceps are specialized ophthalmic instruments used primarily for corneal suturing, featuring a platform-like tip to gently hold eye tissues during delicate procedures.

questions.text: A patient presented with unilateral proptosis and bilateral abducent palsy. What is the most probable cause?  (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cavernous sinus thrombosis

 

  • Clinical scenario suggests cavernous sinus thrombosis.
  • Features include early involvement of lateral rectus palsy due to involvement of abducent nerve passing through the cavernous sinus.
  • Later involvement of oculomotor and trochlear nerve palsy, related to the lateral wall of cavernous sinus.

*image added

 

 

  • Other signs include proptosis, severe supraorbital pain, edema in mastoid region, absence of corneal sensation, and dilated pupil.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Retinoblastoma: Occurs in young children and presents with unilateral proptosis with leukocoria, buphthalmos, and squint.

 

Option B. Orbital pseudotumor: Presents with unilateral proptosis with diplopia, conjunctival chemosis. The inflammation is responsive to systemic corticosteroids.

 

Option C. Orbital cellulitis: Presents with unilateral proptosis with pain and decreased ocular motility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cavernous sinus thrombosis is a medical emergency. Rapid recognition and aggressive treatment are essential to prevent serious complications and improve patient outcomes.

questions.text: What is the most common ocular manifestation of COVID-19?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Follicular conjunctivitis

 

COVID-19 can cause various ocular manifestations, with follicular conjunctivitis being the most common. This is due to the presence of ACE-2 receptors in the cornea and conjunctiva, making them susceptible to SARS-CoV-2 infection.

 

COVID-19:

 

  • Most common ocular symptoms: Dry eye or foreign body sensation, redness, tearing, itching, eye pain, and discharge.
  • Most common ocular manifestation: Mild follicular conjunctivitis, which can appear as the only sign and symptom of COVID-19.
  • Other less frequent ocular complications: Hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, dry eye disease, episcleritis, chemosis, and photophobia.
  • Intraocular complications that may occur: Retinal artery occlusions, hemorrhages, and cotton wool spots caused by complement-mediated thrombotic angiopathy.
  • Patients with conjunctivitis should undergo a nasopharyngeal RT-PCR test for COVID-19 to rule out systemic infection.
  • Physicians and ophthalmologists should exercise caution when examining patients with conjunctivitis and wear eye-protective gear in addition to face masks and other protective devices.

 

FOLLICULAR CONJUNCTIVITIS:

 

 

  • The follicles appear as gray-white, round to oval elevations which measuring between 0.5 to 1.5 mm in diameter
  • Smaller follicles may produce a slightly irregular and velvety appearance
  • Follicles can be seen in the inferior and superior tarsal conjunctiva, and less often, on bulbar or limbal conjunctiva 
    • Acute follicular conjunctivitis is usually associated with viral (epidemic keratoconjunctivitis, Herpes zoster keratoconjunctivitis, infectious mononucleosis, Epstein-Barr virus infection) or chlamydial infections (Inclusion conjunctivitis), while chronic disease may be caused by chronic chlamydial infection (trachoma, lymphogranuloma venereum) or as a toxic or reactive inflammatory response to topical medications and molluscum contagiosum infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uveitis: There are no consistent reports linking uveitis directly as a common manifestation of COVID-19.

 

Option B. Mucormycosis: Although mucormycosis (commonly known as black fungus) has been seen in COVID-19 patients, it is generally associated with severely immunocompromised states and not directly linked as a typical ocular manifestation of COVID-19 itself.

 

Option D. Papillary Conjunctivitis: This type of conjunctivitis, characterized by cobblestone-like nodules, is more commonly associated with allergic reactions or chronic irritation from contact lenses rather than infectious etiologies like COVID-19.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 60-year-old presents with chronic dacryocystitis. What should be the treatment of choice? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dacryocystorhinostomy

 

In a 60-year-old patient presenting with chronic dacryocystitis, the treatment of choice is dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR). Chronic dacryocystitis involves the inflammation and obstruction of the nasolacrimal duct, leading to persistent tearing and infection. In adults, this condition typically requires surgical intervention to create a new drainage pathway.

 

DCR surgery involves creating a passage between the lacrimal sac and the middle meatus of the nasal cavity. This bypasses the blocked nasolacrimal duct and allows tears to drain directly into the nose. The procedure effectively resolves the symptoms and prevents recurrent infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lacrimal sac massage: This is typically recommended for congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction in infants, not for chronic dacryocystitis in adults.

 

Option B. Syringing: This procedure can help to diagnose the site of obstruction and may be used in cases of acute dacryocystitis or in infants, but it is not a definitive treatment for chronic dacryocystitis in adults.

 

Option D. Probing: This is also more commonly used in infants with congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction. In adults, especially those with chronic inflammation, probing alone is usually insufficient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) is the treatment of choice for chronic dacryocystitis in adults, involving the creation of a new drainage pathway between the lacrimal sac and the middle meatus of the nasal cavity to bypass the blocked nasolacrimal duct.

questions.text: A patient presents with neurological symptoms and Kayser-Fleischer rings. What is the best initial screening test for Wilson's disease? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Serum ceruloplasmin

 

In patients presenting with neurological symptoms and Kayser-Fleischer rings suggestive of Wilson's disease, serum ceruloplasmin is the best initial screening test. This is because:

  • It is minimally invasive
  • Has high sensitivity (90%) when combined with KF rings
  • Low levels (<20 mg/dL) are highly suggestive in the appropriate clinical context
  • Can be easily performed before proceeding to more invasive testing

 

The presence of KF rings (copper deposits in Descemet's membrane) as shown in the image strengthens the suspicion of Wilson's disease, making serum ceruloplasmin an appropriate first-line test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Urine copper: While elevated in Wilson's disease, it's better for monitoring treatment rather than initial screening.

 

Option C. Serum copper: Can be misleading as levels may be normal or low due to decreased ceruloplasmin, despite tissue copper overload.

 

Option D. Hepatic copper estimation: While this is the gold standard confirmatory test, it is invasive and not appropriate as an initial screening test. It should be reserved for confirmation after less invasive screening tests.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

When Wilson's disease is suspected based on clinical features like KF rings and neurological symptoms, serum ceruloplasmin is the most appropriate initial screening test before proceeding to more invasive confirmatory testing.

questions.text: Local anesthesia used in cataract surgery is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lignocaine 2%

 

Lignocaine 2% (also known as lidocaine) is the most commonly used local anesthetic for cataract surgery. It provides effective and rapid onset of anesthesia, making it ideal for this type of procedure. Lignocaine is typically used for infiltration anesthesia, which involves injecting the anesthetic around the eye to block nerve impulses.

 

Types of Local Anesthesia:

 

  • Infiltrating Type: This involves injecting the anesthetic directly into the tissue to numb a specific area.
  • Topical: Applied directly to the surface of the skin or mucous membranes. Best drug is proparacain

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bupivacaine 0.5%:  While bupivacaine can be used in ophthalmic surgery, it's generally reserved for cases where longer-lasting anesthesia is required. It's not the first choice for routine cataract surgery.

 

Option C. Prilocaine 0.5%:  Prilocaine is sometimes used in dental procedures but is not commonly used in ophthalmic surgery.

 

Option D. Ropivacaine 0.05%:  Ropivacaine is used in various surgical procedures but is not typically the first choice for cataract surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lignocaine 2% is the standard local anesthetic used in cataract surgery due to its rapid onset and appropriate duration of action. However, it's important to note that topical anesthesia using proparacaine 0.5% is becoming increasingly common in modern cataract surgery techniques.

questions.text: In which condition is pupillary light reaction absent and accommodation reaction present? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neurosyphilis

 

Explanation:

 

The condition described is characteristic of the Argyll Robertson pupil, which is associated with neurosyphilis. In this condition, the pupillary light reflex is absent, meaning the pupils do not constrict in response to light. However, the accommodation reflex, which involves pupil constriction when focusing on a near object, is preserved. This phenomenon is often summarized by the -

 

Mnemonic "ARP and PRA" (Accommodation Reflex Present and Pupillary Reflex Absent).

 

 

 

The underlying mechanism involves damage to the interneurons in the pretectal area of the midbrain, which affects the light reflex pathway while sparing the accommodation pathway.

 

The Near triad, consisting of accommodation, convergence, and miosis, remains intact in neurosyphilis, explaining why accommodation is preserved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Horner’s syndrome: This condition is characterized by ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis due to a disruption in the sympathetic pathways. The pupillary light reaction is not typically absent.

 

Option C. Papilledema: This condition involves swelling of the optic disc due to increased intracranial pressure. The pupillary light reaction is usually normal in papilledema.

 

Option D. Optic neuritis: This inflammation of the optic nerve often leads to a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) or Marcus Gunn pupil, where the affected eye shows a reduced direct response to light. However, the accommodation reaction is not selectively preserved as described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Argyll Robertson pupil, associated with neurosyphilis, presents with absent pupillary light reaction and preserved accommodation reaction, highlighting a distinctive neuro-ophthalmologic sign of this condition.

choices.text: Antibiotic eye drops post surgery

questions.text: After cataract surgery, endophthalmitis developed. How will you prevent post operative endophthalmitis?(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Povidone iodine before surgery 

 

The most widely accepted method for preventing postoperative endophthalmitis is  Povidone-Iodine Before Surgery. It is recognized as a crucial step in the preoperative preparation of cataract surgery to minimize the risk of infection.

 

Povidone-iodine is an effective antiseptic that is widely used to reduce the risk of postoperative endophthalmitis. Applying povidone-iodine to the ocular surface before surgery can significantly decrease the number of pathogenic organisms in the operative field, thereby reducing the risk of postoperative infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intravitreal Anti-bacterial Injections: Intravitreal antibiotics are used as a treatment for established endophthalmitis, not as a prophylactic measure. Giving these injections as a routine prevention measure is not standard due to the potential risks, such as retinal detachment or injection-related infections.

 

Option C. Mydriatics Before Surgery: Mydriatics are medications used to dilate the pupils. They are important for cataract surgery because they provide the surgeon with better visibility of the lens. However, they do not have an antimicrobial effect and therefore would not prevent endophthalmitis.

 

Option D. Antibiotic Eye Drops Post-Surgery: Antibiotic eye drops post-surgery are commonly prescribed as a prophylactic measure to reduce the risk of infection. While their efficacy in preventing endophthalmitis is debated, they are still widely used in the postoperative period.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To prevent postoperative endophthalmitis following cataract surgery, the application of povidone-iodine on the ocular surface before surgery is the standard prophylactic procedure.

questions.text: Diagnose the image seen in a 10-year-old child. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Herbert pits

 

Herbert pits are depressions seen on the cornea, typically found in patients with trachoma, a chronic infectious disease caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. These pits are formed when the follicles, which are lymphocyte aggregates, present at the limbus (called Herbert follicles) rupture or degenerate, leaving behind characteristic pits. This condition is commonly seen in individuals with trachoma who have chronic eye rubbing due to persistent irritation.

 

Other findings of trachoma are –

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Horner Trantas spots: These are white, elevated, gelatinous spots seen at the limbus, usually associated with vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC), an allergic condition of the eye. They are composed of eosinophils and epithelial cells and are not associated with depressions on the cornea.

 

 

Other findings of VKC are –

 

 

Giant papillae, also known as the cobblestone appearance

 

 

Ropey discharge (Maxwell-Leon sign)

 

Option C. Pannus: Pannus is the growth of abnormal blood vessels into the cornea, often accompanied by fibrovascular tissue. This condition is typically seen in trachoma but presents as vascularization rather than depressions.

 

 

Option D. Corneal dystrophy: This refers to a group of genetic disorders that cause the accumulation of abnormal material in the cornea. Corneal dystrophies present with clouding, swelling, or other structural changes in the cornea, not with pits or depressions.

 

 

Educational Objective:


Herbert pits are characteristic depressions found in the cornea due to the rupture of follicles, commonly seen in trachoma.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient complains of a painful, bluish-purple nodular lesion near the limbus as shown, with severe discomfort that persists despite topical medications. The patient also reports morning stiffness in multiple joints. What can be the most probable diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Scleritis with Rheumatoid Arthritis

 

Scleritis is a severe inflammatory condition affecting the sclera itself. The key features supporting this diagnosis are:

  • Intense, severe pain that is not relieved by topical medications
  • Bluish-purple hue (due to deep inflammation)
  • Association with systemic autoimmune conditions, particularly rheumatoid arthritis
  • Deep vascular involvement requiring systemic therapy

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Episcleritis with Rheumatoid Arthritis: While also associated with RA, episcleritis typically presents with mild discomfort and responds well to topical therapy. The pain is less severe, and the color is bright red rather than bluish-purple.

 

Option C. Pinguecula and Dry Eye: Pinguecula is a degenerative condition presenting as a yellowish elevation without significant inflammation or pain.

 

 

Option D. Pterygium and Astigmatism: Pterygium is a wing-shaped fibrovascular growth extending onto the cornea, not presenting as a nodular lesion with severe pain.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scleritis can be distinguished from episcleritis by:

  1. Severe pain not responding to topical therapy
  2. Bluish-purple discoloration
  3. Need for systemic therapy
  4. Strong association with systemic autoimmune diseases
  5. Higher risk of vision-threatening complications if untreated

questions.text:
A pregnant woman presented with total ophthalmoplegia, pulsatile proptosis of the right eye, retroorbital pain accompanied with fever and headache. On examination, fundus and BP were normal. Which of the following structures are involved?

 

  1. Abducens nerve
  2. Oculomotor nerve
  3. Internal carotid artery
  4. Cavernous sinus
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

The clinical presentation of pulsatile proptosis, retroorbital pain, fever, and headache in a pregnant woman suggests the involvement of multiple cranial structures, primarily those associated with the cavernous sinus, a critical venous sinus at the base of the brain that acts as a conduit for venous blood drainage from the brain and eye. This constellation of symptoms and signs is indicative of cavernous sinus thrombosis (CST), a severe and potentially life-threatening condition.

 

  • Cavernous sinus thrombosis (CST) is a septic thrombus formed in the cavernous sinus due to the spread of infection from sinuses, teeth, ears, nose, and skin of the face.
  • Symptoms include fever, severe headache, supraorbital pain, seizures, and edema in the mastoid region.
  • Eye signs include proptosis, chemosis, and diplopia due to ophthalmoplegia from the involvement of oculomotor (CN-III), trochlear (CN-IV), and abducens nerve (CN-VI).
  • Absence of corneal sensation due to the involvement of the ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve (CN-V1)
  • Ipsilateral ptosis, dilated pupil, and absence of direct and consensual pupillary right reflex due to oculomotor nerve palsy.
  • Pulsatile proptosis occurs with the involvement of the internal carotid artery.
  • Brain magnetic resonance imaging or magnetic resonance venography should be done urgently for diagnosis.
  • Management of CST includes intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics, analgesics, anti-inflammatory drugs, and anticoagulants.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 1-week-old child presented with severe jaundice, hemolysis, and dark urine. The child developed cyanosis after consuming fava beans in breast milk. This can be caused due to the deficiency of which enzyme? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD)

 

The clinical presentation is characteristic of G6PD deficiency, characterized by:

  • Acute hemolytic crisis in neonates
  • Severe jaundice requiring phototherapy/exchange transfusion
  • Trigger by oxidative stress (fava beans, certain drugs)
  • Dark urine due to hemoglobinuria
  • Cyanosis due to methemoglobinemia

 

G6PD is crucial because it:

  • Generates NADPH in red blood cells
  • Protects against oxidative stress
  • Maintains glutathione in reduced state
  • Prevents hemolysis under oxidative conditions

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Catalase: While involved in oxidative stress protection, catalase deficiency doesn't cause significant hemolysis or the clinical picture described.

 

Option B. Galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase: Deficiency causes galactosemia, presenting with cataracts, feeding issues, and liver dysfunction, but not hemolysis triggered by fava beans.

 

Option D. Hexokinase: This enzyme phosphorylates glucose and isn't directly involved in red cell protection against oxidative stress.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

G6PD deficiency is an X-linked disorder presenting with acute hemolysis triggered by oxidative stress. Early recognition is crucial to prevent triggers and manage acute crises effectively.

questions.text: A 50-year-old emmetropic man is no longer able to read with the presbyopic glasses he had made 5 years ago. The power of his new prescription glasses should be:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. +2D

 

Since, the question asks for the new prescription, the answer should be +2.00D.

 

Had the question asked us to estimate the power of his old glasses, it would have been +1.5 DS.

 

The power of the prescription glasses for a 50-year-old man should be +2D.

 

This condition of falling near vision due to age-related decrease in the amplitude of accommodation or increase in punctum proximum is called presbyopia.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Emmetropic Man: The patient has no refractive error for distance vision but is experiencing difficulty with near vision due to presbyopia.
  • Current Glasses: If the patient had glasses made 5 years ago (when he was around 45), those glasses were likely around +1.5 D.
  • New Prescription: As presbyopia progresses, the strength of the glasses needs to be increased to +2.0 D to accommodate the further decline in near vision.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Roughly, the power of prescription glasses age-wise is as follows:

questions.text: A patient has presented for a routine eye evaluation. You have checked his visual acuity using Snellen's chart and found it to be 6/6. What is the minimum angle of resolution? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 5 minutes of arc

 

The angle subtended for a patient with 6/6 vision is 5 minutes of arc.

 

Visual acuity is a measure of the spatial resolution of the eye or an estimation of its ability to discriminate between two points.

 

Snellen's chart consists of a series of letters arranged in lines, each diminishing in size. Each whole letter will subtend the angle of 5 minutes at the nodal point of the eye at the given distance.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The minimum angle of resolution for someone with a visual acuity of 6/6 using a Snellen chart is 5 minutes of arc. This indicates the precise and detailed visual capability required to resolve fine details at a standard distance, a fundamental concept in understanding and assessing visual acuity in clinical settings.

questions.text: A patient presents with vision problem in his right eye. On examination IOP of his right eye is 50 mmHg and left eye is 16 mm Hg. Slit lamp examination shows presence of flare cells in anterior chamber and cataractous lens in the right eye. What is the diagnosis of this condition? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phacolytic glaucoma


Phacolytic glaucoma occurs when high intraocular pressure (IOP) is associated with a mature or hypermature cataract. The patient's right eye exhibits high IOP (50 mmHg), flare cells in the anterior chamber, and a cataractous lens, all of which are characteristic signs of phacolytic glaucoma. The leakage of lens material into the anterior chamber induces an inflammatory response, causing the observed clinical signs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malignant glaucoma: This condition typically features a shallow or flat anterior chamber, which contrasts with the described deep anterior chamber. Therefore, it is not consistent with the clinical findings of this patient.

 

Option C. Fuch heterochromic iridocyclitis: This is usually a unilateral condition characterized by chronic inflammation, heterochromia (differences in iris color), and low-grade inflammation. It does not typically present with such high IOP or a cataractous lens as the primary issue.

 

Option D. Phacomorphic glaucoma: This type of glaucoma occurs due to lens-induced angle closure and is associated with a shallow anterior chamber. The patient, however, has a deep anterior chamber, which rules out this diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:


Phacolytic glaucoma is characterized by high intraocular pressure, presence of flare cells in the anterior chamber, and a cataractous lens.

questions.text: Which anti-TB drug causes red colour vision defects or optic neuropathy?(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ethambutol

 

Ethambutol is used in the treatment of tuberculosis. One of the well-known side effects of ethambutol is optic neuropathy, which can lead to color vision defects, particularly with the perception of red and green. Patients on ethambutol are usually monitored for visual acuity and color vision changes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rifampicin: Rifampicin is used to treat various bacterial infections, including tuberculosis (TB). While it has a range of side effects, red color vision defects or optic neuropathy are not typically associated with rifampicin. It is more commonly known to cause orange discoloration of body fluids.

 

Option C. INH (Isoniazid): INH, or isoniazid, is another first-line anti-TB medication. Its side effects can include peripheral neuropathy, which is why it is often given with pyridoxine (vitamin B6) to mitigate this risk. However, INH is not commonly associated with red color vision defects or optic neuropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethambutol, an anti-TB drug, can cause optic neuropathy and red color vision defects, necessitating regular eye exams for patients on this medication.

questions.text: A patient presented with sudden, painful diminution of vision, difficulty in vision in light, and circumferential congestion with corneal edema and fixed mid-dilated pupil as shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute Congestive Glaucoma

 

Acute Congestive (Angle-Closure) Glaucoma is characterized by sudden onset of severe eye pain, blurred vision, and redness. The key distinguishing features in this case are:

 

Key clinical signs:

 

  1. Fixed, mid-dilated pupil - A characteristic finding in acute glaucoma due to iris ischemia and paralysis
  2. Corneal edema - Caused by elevated intraocular pressure leading to stromal swelling and cloudiness
  3. Circumciliary congestion - Deep red discoloration around the cornea due to vascular congestion
  4. Shallow anterior chamber - Though not clearly visible in the image, this is a predisposing factor
  5. Severe pain and reduced vision - Due to acute elevation of intraocular pressure

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute Anterior Uveitis: While this also presents with painful red eye, it typically shows a miotic pupil and hypopyon, not the mid-dilated pupil seen here.

 

 

Option C. Acute Conjunctivitis: Presents with superficial redness and discharge, without corneal edema or pupillary abnormalities.

 

 

Option D. Episcleritis: Causes sectoral redness without affecting the pupil or cornea, and pain is typically mild.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute angle-closure glaucoma can be distinguished from other causes of red eye by its characteristic mid-dilated pupil, corneal edema, and severe pain. This represents an ocular emergency requiring immediate treatment to prevent permanent vision loss.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of moderate-severe visual impairment according to the National Blindness and Visual Impairment Survey 2015-19?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Untreated cataract

 

The National Blindness and Visual Impairment Survey conducted from 2015 to 2019 revealed that untreated cataract is the leading cause of moderate-severe visual impairment (MSVI). MSVI is characterized by a presenting visual acuity of <6/18 to 3/60 in the better eye despite available correction. Visual impairment and blindness are frequently observed in individuals who are 50 years old and above.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Refractive errors are the leading cause of MSVI in patients aged 49 years and below.

 

Options C and Option D: Glaucoma and diabetic retinopathy account for a very low number of visual impairment cases in patients aged 50 years and above.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The prevalence of untreated cataracts as a leading cause of moderate-severe visual impairment emphasizes the need for effective public health strategies focusing on eye health screenings and accessible cataract surgery to reduce the burden of preventable blindness and visual impairment.

questions.text: What is the most common complication associated with the following abnormality? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Exposure keratopathy

 

  • The given image shows a coloboma of the upper eyelid. The most common complication associated with this condition is exposure keratopathy since the defect leaves the cornea exposed. If left untreated, it can lead to corneal ulceration.

 

CONGENITAL EYELID COLOBOMA

 

  • Can be unilateral or bilateral, involving one or all four lids.
  • The defect may vary from a small marginal notch to a full-thickness absence of the entire eyelid margin involving one-third to half of the eyelid.
  • The upper eyelid is commonly affected.
  • The most common site is the junction between the medial and middle third of the upper eyelid.
  • Eyelid colobomas represent an incomplete form of cryptophthalmos. Cryptophthalmos is a congenital condition in which there is a failure of differentiation of eyelid structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Restricted eye movements: This is not a primary complication of eyelid coloboma. Restricted eye movements are more associated with orbital or extraocular muscle issues.

 

Option C. Diplopia: Diplopia, or double vision, is not a common complication of eyelid coloboma. It usually arises from misalignment of the eyes or neurological conditions.

 

Option D. Amblyopia: Amblyopia, or lazy eye, can occur due to vision deprivation in severe cases of eyelid abnormalities, but it is not the most common complication of eyelid coloboma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eyelid colobomas can be an isolated finding or can be associated with various syndromes mentioned below:

questions.text: Normal commensal conjunctival flora are: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Staph. epidermidis

 

Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most common normal commensal flora found on the conjunctiva. This bacterium is typically found on human skin and mucous membranes, including the surface of the eye. It's important to note that while S. epidermidis is usually harmless, it can become opportunistic and cause infections, particularly in immunocompromised individuals or following eye surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Staph. aureus:  While S. aureus can be found on the conjunctiva, it's not as common as S. epidermidis and is more often associated with infections rather than normal flora.

 

Option C. H. influenzae:  This is not typically considered part of the normal conjunctival flora. It's more commonly associated with respiratory infections and can cause conjunctivitis when present in the eye.

 

Option D. Strep. pneumoniae:  This bacterium is not typically part of the normal conjunctival flora. It's more commonly associated with respiratory infections and can cause serious eye infections when present.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most common normal commensal flora of the conjunctiva. It's crucial to manage this normal flora during eye surgeries to prevent postoperative endophthalmitis. The use of povidone-iodine in the immediate pre-operative period is considered the best practice for preventing endophthalmitis by reducing the population of normal commensal flora on the ocular surface.

questions.text: Identify the given instrument: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wire Speculum

 

The instrument shown in the image is a wire speculum. It is characterized by its wire-like structure with two loops at the ends and a central hinge mechanism. Wire specula are commonly used in ophthalmic surgeries such as cataract surgery, glaucoma surgery, and pterygium surgery. Their primary function is to keep the eyelids apart, providing clear access to the eye during procedures. The surgeon squeezes the instrument to open it, places it between the eyelids, and then releases it to hold the lids open.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lid Clamp:  Incorrect. A lid clamp has a different structure, typically with flat surfaces for gripping the eyelid during lid surgeries like entropion or ectropion repairs.
 

 

Option C. Lid Retractor: Incorrect. A lid retractor usually has a plate-like structure at the front and a handle, used for procedures requiring broader lid retraction.

 

 

Option D. Cat's Paw Retractor: Incorrect. This instrument has a fork-like structure at the end and is commonly used in dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) surgery.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A wire speculum is a key instrument in ophthalmic surgery, used to keep the eyelids open and provide access to the eye during various procedures. Its characteristic wire-like structure with loops at the ends distinguishes it from other lid manipulation instruments.

questions.text: Which of the following is the site of lesion in internuclear ophthalmoplegia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Medial Longitudinal Fasciculus

 

Medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF): pair of tracts that interconnect CN VI and CN III nuclei. Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) occurs due to a lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), which is responsible for coordinating horizontal eye movements. The command for left gaze originates from the right cerebral cortex and travels to the left paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF). From there, an output goes to the left VI nerve nucleus, which supplies the left lateral rectus muscle, causing abduction. Another output from the left PPRF goes to the right III nerve nucleus via the right MLF, causing the right eye to adduct.

 

If there is a lesion in the right MLF, it leads to the failure of adduction of the right eye. However, the left eye abducts normally. This is the classic presentation of INO.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 6th Nerve nucleus: A lesion here would result in an inability to abduct the eye on the same side, not INO.

 

Option C. Pontine paramedian reticular formation (PPRF): A lesion here would typically affect both the initiation of gaze to the ipsilateral side and horizontal gaze coordination, leading to symptoms different from typical INO.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classic presentation of internuclear ophthalmoplegia involves a failure of adduction in the affected eye due to a lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus. Recognizing this pathway and its role in horizontal eye movement coordination is crucial for diagnosing and understanding the clinical manifestations of INO.

questions.text: Which of the following would be prescribed for simple myopic astigmatism?  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. -1.00 DC X 180 degree

 

  • The correct prescription for simple myopic astigmatism is -1.00 DC × 180 degrees.
  • Simple myopic astigmatism means that one principal meridian of the eye is in focus on the retina, while the other principal meridian is in front of the retina.
  • There are three components to the prescription of glasses for astigmatism: 
    1. The power of the spherical component (convex or concave dioptre sphere),
    2. The power of the cylinder (convex or concave dioptre cylinder),
    3. The axis (orientation) of the cylinder.

 

For example: -1.00 DC × 180 degree

 

This prescription indicates that the individual has simple astigmatism, which means one meridian of the eye is in focus while the other is not. In this case, the unfocused meridian is myopic (nearsighted) and requires correction with a concave cylinder lens. The strength of the cylinder lens is -1.00 diopters (DC). The axis of the cylinder is oriented at 180 degrees, which represents the meridian that is most affected by astigmatism.

 

Types of astigmatism:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. +1.00 DS: This represents a convex spherical lens for hypermetropia (farsightedness) and is not used for astigmatism correction.

 

Option C. -1.00 DS: This represents a concave spherical lens for simple myopia (nearsightedness) but does not correct astigmatism.

 

Option D. -1.00 DS -1.00 DC X 180 degree: This represents a prescription for compound myopic astigmatism, where both meridians are myopic, one corrected by the spherical component and the other by the cylindrical component.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Simple myopic astigmatism requires correction with a cylindrical lens that corrects the myopic meridian, typically specified with the cylinder power and the axis. The correct prescription for simple myopic astigmatism in this case is -1.00 DC X 180 degrees.

questions.text: Roth spots are seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Acute leukemia

 

  • Roth's spots are retinal hemorrhages with white or pale centers, named after Moritz Roth.
  • Roth spots are classically described in and are considered as pathognomonic of Subacute Bacterial Endocarditis with the yellowish-white centre consisting of a focus of embolic infection.
  • They are commonly seen in other conditions as well.
  • In leukaemia, the white center typically represents fibrin-platelet plugs.
  • Roth's spots are composed of coagulated fibrin, including platelets, focal ischemia, inflammatory infiltrate, infectious organisms, or neoplastic cells.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uveal melanoma: A primary cancer of the eye involving the iris, ciliary body, or choroid, not typically associated with Roth spots.

 

Option C. Uveal lymphoma: A rare type of eye cancer affecting the uvea, not commonly associated with Roth spots.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Roth's spots may be seen in -

 

1. Leukemia

2. Diabetes

3. Subacute bacterial endocarditis

4. Hypertensive retinopathy

5. HIV retinopathy

6. Systemic lupus erythematosus

7. Anemia

8. Pre-eclampsia

9. Anoxi

questions.text: A 72-year-old diabetic patient had undergone surgery for cataract.  6 weeks post-operatively, the patient came with inflammation, decreased vision. On further examination, honeycomb appearance of retina is seen. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cystoid macular edema

 

The postoperative period, presence of inflammation, decreased vision, and the characteristic honeycomb appearance of the retina are indicative of CME.

 

When CME develops following cataract surgery and its cause is thought to be directly related to the surgery, it is referred to as Irvine-Gass syndrome or pseudophakic CME.

 

Cystoid Macular Edema (CME) involves fluid accumulation within the macula, the central part of the retina, leading to swelling and cyst-like spaces, which can create a honeycomb appearance on optical coherence tomography (OCT). CME is a common complication after cataract surgery, particularly in diabetic patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CSR (Central Serous Retinopathy): Central serous retinopathy is characterized by the accumulation of fluid under the retina, which can cause visual disturbances. It often presents with a serous detachment of the central retina. The classic appearance is not honeycomb-like, and CSR is typically not associated with inflammation.

 

Option C. Retinal Detachment: Retinal detachment is a serious condition where the retina peels away from its underlying layer of support tissue. The classic symptoms are the sudden appearance of floaters, flashes, and a shadow or curtain over part of the visual field. The honeycomb pattern is not characteristic of retinal detachment.

 

Option D. Diabetic Retinopathy: Diabetic retinopathy is a complication of diabetes caused by damage to the blood vessels of the light-sensitive tissue at the retina. It typically presents with dot and blot hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and neovascularization. While macular edema can occur in diabetic retinopathy, the description of a postoperative honeycomb appearance of the retina is more specific to cystoid macular edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a diabetic patient presenting with postoperative inflammation and decreased vision featuring a honeycomb appearance of the retina, the likely diagnosis is cystoid macular edema.

questions.text: A patient presents with diminution of vision. He has a H/o ATT intake. The causative drug is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ethambutol

 

Ethambutol is the most likely causative drug for vision problems in patients taking anti-tubercular therapy (ATT). It can cause toxic optic neuropathy, leading to diminution of vision. This side effect is dose-dependent and usually reversible if detected early and the drug is discontinued. Ethambutol primarily affects the optic nerve, causing decreased visual acuity, altered color perception (especially red-green color blindness), and central scotomas.

 

Toxic Amblyopia caused by drugs:

 

  • Ethambutol
  • Tobacco
  • Chloroquine
  • Hydroxychloroquine
  • Quinine
  • Ethyl Alcohol
  • Methyl Alcohol

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiazinamide: This drug is not commonly used in ATT and is not typically associated with vision problems.

 

Option B. Rifampicin: While an important component of ATT, rifampicin is not primarily associated with vision changes. Its main side effects include hepatotoxicity and orange discoloration of body fluids.

 

Option C. Isoniazid: Although isoniazid can cause peripheral neuropathy, it is not typically associated with optic neuropathy or vision changes. Its main neurological side effect is peripheral neuropathy, which can be prevented by administering pyridoxine (vitamin B6).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethambutol is the anti-tubercular drug most commonly associated with toxic optic neuropathy, causing diminution of vision in patients on ATT. Regular ophthalmic monitoring is crucial for patients on ethambutol to detect early signs of toxicity

questions.text: What are the yoke muscles for levodepression? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) R SO and LIR

 

In ocular motility, yoke muscles are pairs of muscles from each eye that work together to move the eyes in the same direction. For levodepression, which is movement of the eyes to the left and downward, the yoke muscles involved are the right superior oblique (R SO) and the left inferior rectus (LIR).

 

When the eye moves to the left (levoversion), the left eye’s inferior rectus muscle depresses the eye, while the right eye’s superior oblique muscle assists in depressing the right eye. This coordinated action ensures both eyes move together smoothly.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. R LR and LMR: These are the right lateral rectus and left medial rectus muscles, responsible for horizontal eye movements, not depression.

 

Option B. R SR and LIR: The right superior rectus is an elevator of the right eye, not a depressor.

 

Option D. R IO and LSO: The right inferior oblique elevates the right eye, and the left superior oblique depresses the left eye, which does not fit the movement described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The yoke muscles responsible for levodepression (movement of the eyes to the left and downward) are the right superior oblique and the left inferior rectus.

questions.text: Presence of different refractive powers (+5D in one eye and +1D in the other eye) in a 10-year-old boy is suggestive of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anisometropic amblyopia

 

 

Anisometropic amblyopia is the most appropriate diagnosis in this case. It occurs when there is a significant difference in refractive error between the two eyes (typically more than 2.5 diopters). In this scenario, the difference is 4 diopters (+5D in one eye and +1D in the other), which exceeds the threshold. This difference can lead to unequal visual inputs during the critical period of visual development, resulting in amblyopia or "lazy eye" in the eye with the higher refractive error.

 

Causes of Amblyopia:

 

  1. Stimulus Deprivation Amblyopia: Typically occurs if there's a visual obstruction during developmental years, such as congenital cataract. Even after the obstruction (e.g., cataract) is surgically removed, the affected eye may not achieve normal vision due to the lack of proper visual stimuli during a critical period of visual development.
  2. Strabismic Amblyopia: Occurs when one eye deviates away (strabismus) and does not focus in alignment with the other eye, leading the deviated eye to be underused and become 'lazy.'
  3. Anisometropic Amblyopia: Arises from a significant difference in refractive errors between the two eyes, causing one eye to be less used than the other.
  4. Isoametropic (or ametropic) Amblyopia: Both eyes have high refractive errors and have not been corrected during critical developmental years, leading to underdevelopment in visual acuity in both eyes.

 

The primary treatment for amblyopia involves patching the stronger eye. This forces the amblyopic (lazy) eye to work harder, promoting visual development and function. This method is most effective during the early years, aligning with the critical period of visual development.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amblyopia:  While this is partially correct, it's the second best answer. Amblyopia is a visual development disorder where an eye fails to achieve normal visual acuity, devoid of any detectable structural issues of the eye.

 

Option C. Malingering:  Incorrect. This refers to intentional feigning or exaggeration of symptoms, which is not suggested by the given clinical scenario.

 

Option D. Refractive errors:  While refractive errors are present, this answer doesn't capture the key issue of the significant difference between the eyes and its potential consequences.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A difference in refractive power between the two eyes of more than 2.5 diopters can lead to anisometropic amblyopia, especially if untreated during the critical period of visual development (up to about 7 years of age)

questions.text: A mother brought her 3-year-old child with cataract for second opinion. The child appears orthotropic and fine. What will be the management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cataract surgery

 

The likely management if the cataract is visually significant would be Cataract Surgery. Early intervention with cataract surgery is critical in children to prevent amblyopia and ensure proper visual development. Cataract surgery is the removal of the lens of the eye that has become opaque. In children, this is typically followed by the implantation of an intraocular lens.

 

Given the child is orthotropic (has normal eye alignment) and seems fine, the management would depend on the severity of the cataract and its effect on the child's vision. If the cataract is significant and affecting the child's vision, potentially leading to amblyopia, then cataract surgery would be the appropriate management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Convergence of Eye Muscle Exercises: are used to strengthen the eye muscles to improve binocular vision and treat convergence insufficiency. However, they are not a treatment for cataracts, which is a lens-related issue and not a muscle issue.

 

Option B. Reassurance: might be given if the cataract is very mild and not significantly affecting the child's vision. However, in children, even mild cataracts can lead to amblyopia (lazy eye) if not treated in a timely manner because visual development is ongoing.

 

Option D. Pilocarpine: is a medication used to constrict the pupil and reduce intraocular pressure, and it can also be used to manage acute angle-closure glaucoma. It is not a treatment for cataracts and would not be used as such in a child.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a 3-year-old child presenting with cataract, the management typically involves cataract surgery to prevent amblyopia and ensure normal visual development, unless the cataract is not significantly affecting vision.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of complicated cataracts? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Krukenberg spindle

 

Krukenberg spindle is not a feature of complicated cataracts. The slit lamp examination in pigmentary glaucoma shows a pattern of pigment deposition on the back of the cornea-endothelium called Krukenberg spindles.

 

 

  • Complicated or secondary cataracts develop due to inflammatory or degenerative conditions of the lens or other parts of the eye.
  • Causes of these cataracts include iridocyclitis and ciliary body tumors which disturb the nutrition of the lens.
  • These cataracts present with a breadcrumb appearance and polychromatic luster.
  • Vision impairment occurs even in the early stages due to location of the cataract at the nodal point.
  • Inflammation of the posterior segment causes posterior subcapsular cataract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Polychromatic lustre: This is a feature seen in complicated cataracts where the lens exhibits a colorful sheen, often described as having a "christmas tree" or polychromatic appearance, particularly noticeable under slit-lamp examination.

 

Option C. Occurs after uveitis: Uveitis, an inflammatory disease affecting the uveal tract of the eye, can lead to the development of complicated cataracts. Chronic inflammation can disrupt the lens, leading to cataract formation.

 

Option D. Breadcrumb appearance: This refers to the appearance of small opacities within the lens, resembling breadcrumbs, commonly seen in complicated cataracts due to intraocular inflammation or other degenerative changes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Krukenberg spindle is a vertical, spindle-shaped deposit of pigment on the posterior surface of the cornea, commonly seen in pigmentary glaucoma. It results from the dispersion of pigment granules from the iris that adhere to the corneal endothelium.

questions.text: Vitamin A deficiency is characteristic of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bitot spots

 

Bitot spots are a characteristic sign of vitamin A deficiency. They appear as dry, foamy, triangular patches on the conjunctiva, typically on the temporal side of the cornea. These spots are part of a condition called xerophthalmia, which is dryness of the eye due to vitamin A deficiency. Bitot spots represent a more advanced stage of xerophthalmia, classified as stage X1B in the WHO classification of vitamin A deficiency.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stocker's line: This is an iron deposition line seen in front of a pterygium. It is not related to vitamin A deficiency.

 

 

Option B. Pinguecula: This is a yellowish, raised lesion on the conjunctiva near the corneal limbus. It's caused by elastotic degeneration due to prolonged UV exposure, not vitamin A deficiency.

 

 

Option C. Pterygium: This is a wing-shaped growth of conjunctiva extending onto the cornea. Like pinguecula, it's associated with UV exposure and not vitamin A deficiency.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bitot spots are a characteristic sign of vitamin A deficiency, appearing as dry, foamy patches on the conjunctiva and representing stage X1B of xerophthalmia.

questions.text: Identify the instrument:  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Maddox rod

 

The above instrument is a Maddox rod.

 

A Maddox rod is a specially constructed device, consisting of a series of parallel cylinders, that converts a point source of light into a line image. It can be used to test for horizontal and vertical deviations, and when used in conjunction with another Maddox rod, for cyclo deviations.

 

Maddox Rod Test

 

Patient is asked to fix on a point light in the centre of Maddox tangent scale at a distance of 6 metres. A Maddox rod (which consists of many glass rods of red colour set together in a metallic disc) is placed in front of one eye with axis of the rod parallel to the axis of deviation.

 

 

 

Due to dissimilar images of the two eyes, fusion is broken and heterophoria becomes manifest. The number on the Maddox tangent scale where the red line falls will be the amount of heterophoria in degrees.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maddox wing: An instrument used to measure the horizontal and vertical deviations at near using a different mechanism involving a scale and moving wings.

 

Option B. Maddox glass: This term is not commonly used; it might refer to the Maddox rod or Maddox wing.

 

Option D. Phoropter: An instrument used in refraction testing to determine eyeglass prescriptions, consisting of multiple lenses that can be rotated into place to assess visual acuity and lens power.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Maddox rod is an instrument consisting of parallel cylindrical lenses used to convert a point light source into a line image, aiding in the diagnosis of horizontal, vertical, and cyclo deviations in ocular alignment.

questions.text: What is the drug used for refraction in a child with squint? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1% Atropine

 

Explanation:

 

1% Atropine is the preferred drug for refraction in a child (<7 yr children) with squint, particularly because it is the strongest cycloplegic agent available.

 

Children often have strong accommodation, which can interfere with accurate refraction, especially in cases of accommodative esotropia. Using a potent cycloplegic like 1% atropine helps to fully relax the accommodation, allowing for precise measurement of refractive errors.

 

Atropine 1% is typically preferred in ointment form due to its longer duration of action and ease of application. The ointment can be applied to the eyelashes or lower lid, ensuring widespread coverage over the entire eye surface. This is especially useful for children under the age of 7 who require thorough cycloplegia for accurate refraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tropicamide: This is a short-acting cycloplegic used primarily in adults. It is not strong enough to overcome the strong accommodation seen in children.

 

Option C. Homatropine: Although it has cycloplegic properties, it is less potent than atropine and not the first choice for children with squint.

 

Option D. Cyclopentolate: This is another cycloplegic agent used in children, but it is less potent than atropine. It can be used if atropine is not available or in specific cases where a slightly less strong cycloplegic is sufficient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

1% Atropine is the drug of choice for refraction in children with squint due to its strong cycloplegic effect, ensuring accurate measurement of refractive errors by fully relaxing accommodation.

 

Mnemonic – ACHT  - Order of Potency -

Atropine strongest potency
Cyclopentolate
Homatropine
Tropicamide

questions.text: A patient presents with seizures, hypocalcemia, gum changes, poor wound healing, and lens opacification. Which vitamin must be supplemented to the patient? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin C

 

The clinical presentation is characteristic of scurvy (Vitamin C deficiency), with its hallmark features:

  • Seizures (due to cerebral involvement)
  • Hypocalcemia (vitamin C is needed for calcium absorption)
  • Periodontal changes (bleeding, swollen gums)
  • Poor wound healing (collagen synthesis impairment)
  • Early cataract formation (oxidative stress)

 

Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) is crucial because it:

  • Acts as a cofactor in collagen synthesis
  • Functions as an antioxidant
  • Aids in calcium absorption
  • Supports immune function
  • Enhances wound healing

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B6: While it can cause seizures when deficient, B6 deficiency doesn't typically cause the gum changes and wound healing problems seen here. It's more associated with homocystinuria.

 

Option C. Thiamine: Deficiency causes Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome and beriberi. It doesn't cause the constellation of symptoms described.

 

Option D. Vitamin B2: Riboflavin deficiency primarily affects the cornea and mucous membranes but doesn't cause the extensive symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Vitamin C deficiency can present with diverse manifestations affecting multiple systems, including neurological

questions.text: A 2-month-old baby presented with the following symptoms. What is the ideal treatment for the child? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Immediate surgery

 

The image shows a 2-month-old baby with leukocoria, which refers to a white reflection in the pupil. The differential diagnoses for a 2-month-old presenting with leukocoria include congenital cataract and congenital glaucoma. In both cases, surgery is the definitive treatment.

 

Congenital cataract is more likely in this scenario as the whiteness is confined to the pupil, whereas congenital glaucoma typically causes the entire cornea to appear hazy.

 

 

 

In both the condition, Immediate surgical intervention is crucial to prevent complications like stimulus deprivation amblyopia, which can lead to permanent vision impairment if treatment is delayed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. First try medical management: Medical management is primarily used to manage congenital glaucoma temporarily until surgery can be performed. Once the diagnosis is confirmed, immediate surgery is necessary.

 

Option C. Surgery after 2 years: Delaying surgery to 2 years increases the risk of amblyopia, a condition where the brain starts ignoring signals from the affected eye, leading to vision loss.

 

Option D. Surgery after 6 months of age: Postponing surgery to 6 months also poses a high risk of developing amblyopia, as early surgical intervention is critical to ensure normal visual development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a 2-month-old presenting with leukocoria, immediate surgery is the ideal treatment to prevent amblyopia and ensure proper visual development.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of proptosis in a middle-aged person? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thyroid eye disease

 

Thyroid eye disease (TED), also known as Graves' orbitopathy, is the most common cause of proptosis in middle-aged individuals. TED is an autoimmune condition associated with thyroid dysfunction, typically hyperthyroidism. The disease leads to inflammation and swelling of the extraocular muscles and increased orbital fat, causing the eyes to bulge outward (proptosis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Orbital varix: Orbital varices are venous malformations that can cause intermittent proptosis, but they are not the most common cause. They typically become symptomatic during activities that increase venous pressure, such as straining or bending over.

 

Option C. Retinoblastoma: Retinoblastoma is a malignant intraocular tumor that primarily affects children. It is not a common cause of proptosis in middle-aged adults.

 

Option D. Cavernous hemangioma: Cavernous hemangiomas are benign vascular tumors and the most common orbital tumor in adults, but they are not the most frequent cause of proptosis. These tumors tend to grow slowly and cause progressive proptosis.

 

Intraocular tumours

Most common in adults : Melanoma

Most common in children : Retinoblastoma

 

Intraorbital tumours

Most common in adults : Hemangioma

Most common in children : Rhabdomyosarcoma

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common cause of proptosis in middle-aged individuals is thyroid eye disease (TED), a condition related to thyroid dysfunction that leads to inflammation and swelling within the orbit.

questions.text: Which bones are cut during external DCR?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Maxillary, lacrimal

 

In external Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR),  the maxillary bone is involved because it forms part of the lateral wall of the nasal cavity and part of the orbit. The lacrimal bone is also involved because it contains the lacrimal sac fossa. The surgery involves creating a direct opening between the lacrimal sac and the nasal cavity by removing part of the lacrimal bone and the adjacent part of the maxillary bone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ethmoid, Sphenoid: The ethmoid and sphenoid bones are part of the skull's cranial base and are not typically involved in an external DCR. The ethmoid bone does contribute to the medial wall of the orbit and contains the ethmoid air cells, while the sphenoid bone is part of the skull base and contains the sphenoid sinus.

 

Option B. Ethmoid, Lacrimal: The lacrimal bone is a small bone forming part of the eye socket, and it is indeed involved in DCR as it forms part of the lateral nasal wall and houses part of the nasolacrimal duct. The ethmoid bone, as mentioned, is part of the medial orbital wall but is not typically cut during an external DCR procedure.

 

Option D. Nasal, Lacrimal: The nasal bone forms the bridge of the nose and is not typically modified during an external DCR. The lacrimal bone is involved in the procedure as mentioned, but the nasal bones are not cut.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During an external Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR), the maxillary and lacrimal bones are cut to establish a new tear drainage pathway from the lacrimal sac into the nasal cavity.

questions.text:
Oculocephalic reflex assesses the integrity of which of the following cranial nerves? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

1. III

2. IV

3. VI

4. VIII

5. VII
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3 and 4

 

The oculocephalic reflex, also known as the doll's eye reflex, is a brainstem reflex useful test for evaluating the function of cranial nerves III, VI, and VIII to determine brainstem function and assess brain death.

 

  • It is elicited by the examiner rapidly rotating the patient's head and observing the resulting eye movements. The test is performed in both lateral directions, as well as during flexion and extension of the neck. 
  • The oculomotor (III) nerve receives input from the vestibular (VIII) and abducens (VI) nerves, which relay signals to the brainstem nuclei responsible for generating conjugate eye movements. 
  • In a normal reflex, the eyes move in the opposite direction of head movement to maintain their orientation in space.

 

A negative reflex can indicate cranial nerve palsies or brainstem damage if the eyes do not move or move in the same direction as head movement. 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The oculocephalic reflex assesses the integrity of cranial nerves III (oculomotor), VI (abducens), and VIII (vestibulocochlear), which are crucial for coordinated eye movements in response to head motion.

questions.text: The corrected refractory error is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Presbyopia

 

The "corrected" refractory error, which implies the condition after it has been corrected with appropriate lenses. Presbyopia is unique among the options as it's not a refractive error in the traditional sense, but an age-related condition affecting near vision. When corrected with reading glasses or multifocal lenses, presbyopia allows for clear near vision without altering distance vision, effectively "correcting" the inability to focus on near objects.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myopia: This is a refractive error where distant objects appear blurry. It's corrected with concave (minus) lenses, not the correction itself.

 

Option B. Hypermetropia (Hyperopia):  This condition causes difficulty focusing on near objects and is corrected with convex (plus) lenses, but it's not the corrected state.

 

Option D. Astigmatism:  This is an imperfection in the curvature of the eye's cornea or lens, corrected with cylindrical lenses, but again, it's not the corrected state itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Presbyopia is unique among refractive conditions as its correction (typically with reading glasses) results in clear near vision without altering distance vision, effectively achieving a "corrected" state for both near and far vision

questions.text: Sympathetic ophthalmia is a consequence of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Penetrating ocular trauma

 

  • Sympathetic ophthalmia is a bilateral granulomatous panuveitis seen after a penetrating ocular trauma.
  • It can occur 2 weeks to 3 months after initial injury in 65% of cases, or following intraocular surgery.
  • The injured eye is called ‘exciting eye’ and the fellow eye is called ‘sympathising eye’.
  • The clinical picture of iridocyclitis in the sympathising eye can be divided into two stages:
  • Prodromal stage: 
    • Earliest symptoms: sensitivity to light (photophobia) and transient indistinctness of near objects.
    • Signs: retrolental flare and cells, a few keratic precipitates (KPs), mild ciliary congestion, slight tenderness of the globe, fine vitreous haze, and occasional disc oedema.
  • Fully-developed stage: 
    • Typical signs and symptoms consistent with acute plastic iridocyclitis.
    • Anterior uveitis develops in both eyes, and multifocal choroidal infiltrates with sub-retinal pigment epithelium (RE) infiltrates corresponding to Dalen-Fuchs nodules can be seen in the mid-periphery of the fundus.
  • Treatment includes:
    • High-dose oral prednisolone for several months.
    • Immunosuppressives such as azathioprine, cyclosporine, and methotrexate for resistant cases or as steroid-sparing agents.
    • Enucleation of a severely injured eye with no visual potential within 2 weeks of injury to prevent the occurrence of sympathetic ophthalmia.

 

Differential diagnosis of Sympathetic Ophthalmia is Vogy-Koyanagi-Harada Disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blunt ocular trauma: typically does not cause sympathetic ophthalmia.

 

Option C. Chemical injury: primarily affects the ocular surface and cornea rather than causing granulomatous uveitis.

 

Option D. Urinary tract infection: is unrelated to ocular conditions and does not cause sympathetic ophthalmia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sympathetic ophthalmia is a preventable and treatable condition if diagnosed early and managed appropriately. Awareness of its presentation and prompt treatment can prevent severe bilateral vision loss.

questions.text: An industrial worker was admitted to the hospital after an eye injury sustained while cutting stone with a hammer and iron chisel. A foreign body was suspected to be impacted in his eye. Which investigation can be detrimental to this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. MRI

 

  • MRI can cause movements of an intraocular foreign body (OFB) if it is magnetic and is contraindicated for metallic (iron) foreign bodies.
  • The most common foreign bodies to penetrate and be retained in the eye are minute chips of iron or steel.
  • Foreign bodies entering the eye may cause damage by mechanical effects, introduction of infection, or reacting with the intraocular tissues.
  • Localization of intraocular foreign body can be done through:
    1. Radiographic: Limbal ring method, which is the simplest but sparingly employed technique.
    2. Ultrasonographic: Can tell the position of even non-radio-opaque foreign bodies.
    3. CT scan: Presently the best method of intraocular foreign body localization, providing cross-sectional images with superior sensitivity and specificity than plain radiography and ultrasonography.

 

  • A foreign body should always be removed unless it is inert and probably sterile, little damage has been done to vision, or the process of removal will destroy sight.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CT: CT scan is highly effective for detecting and localizing metallic foreign bodies. It provides detailed cross-sectional images without the risks associated with MRI.

 

Option C. X-ray: X-ray can detect metallic foreign bodies and is a safe initial imaging modality. However, it is less sensitive than CT.

 

Option D. B mode scan: B mode ultrasound can help localize non-radio-opaque foreign bodies and assess intraocular damage. It is safe and commonly used when MRI is contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MRI is contraindicated for patients with suspected metallic foreign bodies in the eye due to the risk of movement and further injury caused by the magnetic fields.

choices.text: The parts of a pterygium are Body, head and cap

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of pterygium? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rate of recurrence is 95%

 

  • Pterygium is a triangular fibrovascular ingrowth of degenerative conjunctival tissue.
  • It is caused by prolonged exposure to UV rays, dry heat, etc.
  • It has three parts: head (apical part on the cornea, body (region between limbus and canthus), and cap (semilunar white infiltrate in front of the head).
  • Patients may experience itching and grittiness due to Dellen.
  • It can interfere with vision and induce astigmatism.
  • Stocker's line may be associated with pterygium, which is a linear deposition of iron seen in the corneal epithelium, anterior to the head of a pterygium.
  • The recurrence rate after simple surgical excision is around 80%.

 

 

  • Pterygium is of 2 types: 
    1. Progressive which is thick, fleshy, and vascular.
    2. Regressive which is thin, atrophic, and attenuated.
  • This condition can be treated symptomatically with tear substitutes for dry eye symptoms and patients are advised to avoid  exposure to sun.
