  • Surgical excision with free conjunctival limbal autograft is the preferred treatment to avoid recurrence.
  • The recurrence rate of pterygium is around 80% after simple surgical excision. Excision together with adjunctive therapies such as mitomycin C or 5-fluorouracil can reduce the risk of recurrence to approximately 10%.
  • Reported Recurrence rate after P.E.R.F.E.C.T technique is 1.6% (Cornelius CR. Recurrence Rate and Complications of Pterygium Extended Removal Followed by Extended Conjunctival Transplant).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It is a fibrovascular growth: This is accurate. Pterygium consists of fibrovascular tissue that can progressively invade the cornea.

 

Option C. The parts of a pterygium are Body, head and cap: This is true. The pterygium is typically described as having three parts: the head (which is the part that extends onto the cornea), the body (the main bulk of the growth), and the cap or leading edge.

 

Option D. Has progressive and regressive types: This is also true. Pterygium can be classified into progressive, which is active, vascular, and may encroach further onto the cornea, and regressive, which is typically less vascular and more fibrotic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pterygium's recurrence after surgical removal depends greatly on the surgical technique and the use of adjuvant therapies, not inherently 95% as previously thought. Effective management includes surgical excision combined with conjunctival autografts and adjuvant therapy to reduce the risk of recurrence significantly.

questions.text: Identify the test being shown below: NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Cover-uncover test

 

The test shown is the cover - uncover test.

 

Cover-uncover test:

 

  • The cover test is used to detect the presence and type of heterophoria.
  • One eye is covered with an occluder while the other eye fixates on an object.
  • The covered eye will deviate if heterophoria is present.
  • After a few seconds, the cover is removed, and the movement of the previously covered eye is observed.
  • The direction of movement of the eyeball indicates the type of heterophoria (e.g., outward movement suggests esophoria).
  • The speed of movement indicates whether recovery is slow or rapid.

 

 

Prism Bar cover test: Cover test is performed with a prism bad to measure deviation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obscure test: Not a standard test for detecting eye alignment issues.

 

Option B. Prism test: A generic term that can refer to various tests involving prisms, including the prism cover test used to measure the degree of deviation.

 

Option D. Maddox rod test: Used to detect and measure phorias and tropias, but involves a Maddox rod and a point light source, creating a line image, not the cover-uncover sequence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cover-uncover test is a simple and effective method to detect and diagnose latent and manifest deviations of the eyes by observing the movement of the uncovered eye during fixation on a target.

questions.text: A patient of HIV with low CD4 count presents with the following finding. Which of the following is used in the treatment of choice? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ganciclovir

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a case of retinitis, a common ocular manifestation in HIV patients with low CD4 counts.

 

Retinitis can be caused by various pathogens, but in the context of HIV with a low CD4 count, Cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis is a significant concern. This condition is typically seen when the CD4 count falls below 100 cells/mm³. CMV retinitis presents with retinal necrosis and can progress rapidly, leading to blindness if not treated promptly.

 

The treatment of choice for CMV retinitis is Ganciclovir, which can be administered intravitreally to deliver the drug directly to the affected site in the eye. Ganciclovir inhibits viral replication by targeting viral DNA polymerase, making it effective against CMV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acyclovir: This antiviral is used primarily for Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) and Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV) infections.

 

Option B. Valacyclovir: This is a prodrug of acyclovir and is also used for HSV and VZV infections.

 

Option C. Tenofovir: This antiviral is used in the treatment of HIV and Hepatitis B virus (HBV) infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ganciclovir is the treatment of choice for CMV retinitis in HIV patients with low CD4 counts, administered intravitreally to manage the infection effectively and prevent blindness.

 

Additional Information

Ocular manifestation of HIV –

questions.text: A 19-year-old youth was brought the casualty with a black eye following a fist fight. Which area of the orbit is most likely to have been fractured? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Floor

 

  • The most common site of an orbital blowout fracture is the floor of the orbit.
  • BLOW-out fractures involve LOW wall (means inferior wall or floor of orbit).
  • The floor consists of three bones: the zygomatic, maxillary, and palatine bones. The posteromedial portion of the maxillary bone is relatively weak and may be involved in a "blowout" fracture.
  • Clinical features:
  • Subconjunctival hemorrhage.
  • Subcutaneous emphysema affecting the eyelids (commoner with medial wall fractures)
  • Enophthalmus (inward displacement of eyeball) and mechanical ptosis
  • Infraorbital nerve anaesthesia
  • Double diplopia (diplopia in both upwards as well as downwards gaze)
  • Positive “forced duction test”
  • Management:
  • X ray (Waters view) and CT-Scan of orbit show tear drop sign.
  • Conservative management may be useful in a good number of patients.
  • However, surgical intervention if required should be done about 2 weeks of injury with synthetic material like supramide, teflon or silicon.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial wall: Less commonly involved in isolated blowout fractures; can be associated with subcutaneous emphysema.

 

Option B. Lateral wall: The strongest wall of the orbit and less likely to fracture in isolated blunt trauma.

 

Option C. Roof: More common in children due to its thinness but less common overall compared to the floor in blowout fractures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The floor of the orbit is the most likely site of fracture in cases of orbital blowout fractures resulting from blunt trauma, such as a fist fight. Key clinical features include enophthalmos, infraorbital nerve anesthesia, and diplopia. Imaging with X-rays and CT scans are crucial for diagnosis and surgical intervention may be required for severe cases.

questions.text: 2 hours after waking up from general anesthesia, a patient complained of eye ache and difficulty in vision. The first line of management must be: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mannitol + Atropine

 

The scenario describes malignant glaucoma (aqueous misdirection syndrome), a rare but severe complication that can occur post-operatively, particularly after anterior segment surgery or general anesthesia. In this condition, aqueous humor is redirected posteriorly, causing forward displacement of the lens-iris diaphragm, leading to secondary angle closure and elevated intraocular pressure (IOP).

 

Mannitol, a hyperosmotic agent, is administered to quickly reduce the vitreous volume and IOP. Unlike primary angle-closure glaucoma, in malignant glaucoma, Atropine is beneficial as it:

  1. Paralyzes the ciliary muscle, reducing aqueous production
  2. Pulls the iris-lens diaphragm posteriorly
  3. Deepens the anterior chamber

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mannitol + Pilocarpine: Pilocarpine would worsen the condition by increasing ciliary muscle contraction and forward movement of the lens-iris diaphragm.

 

Option B. Mannitol + Moxifloxacin: Moxifloxacin is an antibiotic with no role in managing malignant glaucoma.

 

Option D. Mannitol + Timolol: While timolol reduces aqueous production, it doesn't address the fundamental pathology of anterior rotation of the ciliary body and lens-iris diaphragm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first-line management of malignant glaucoma involves using Mannitol to reduce vitreous volume and IOP, combined with cycloplegics like Atropine to posteriorly rotate the ciliary body and lens-iris diaphragm.

questions.text: On retinal examination of a hypertensive patient, multiple flame-shaped hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, and disc edema were seen. Which grade of hypertensive retinopathy will it be classified as? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Grade 4

 

The presence of multiple flame-shaped hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, and disc edema on retinal examination in a hypertensive patient indicates Grade 4 hypertensive retinopathy. This grading is based on the Keith-Wagener-Barker classification system.

 

Keith-Wagener-Barker Classification:

 

  • Grade 1: Mild retinal arteriolar narrowing and sclerosis.
  • Grade 2: More severe arteriolar narrowing with focal irregularities and AV nicking (Salus sign).
  • Grade 3: Presence of retinal hemorrhages (such as flame-shaped hemorrhages) and exudates (cotton wool spots), often referred to as moderate to severe retinopathy.
  • Grade 4: Severe retinopathy with the presence of papilledema (optic disc edema). This is also known as malignant hypertensive retinopathy, is characterized by the presence of papilledema along with retinal hemorrhages and exudates, indicating severe hypertension that requires immediate medical intervention.

 

Papilledema is a hallmark of Grade 4 hypertensive retinopathy, indicating a severe and urgent condition that requires immediate medical attention to manage the underlying hypertension and prevent further complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grade 1: Characterized by mild arteriolar narrowing without hemorrhages, exudates, or disc edema.

 

Option B. Grade 2: Involves more pronounced arteriolar narrowing and AV nicking but lacks hemorrhages, exudates, and disc edema.

 

Option C. Grade 3: Involves hemorrhages and exudates but without the presence of disc edema (papilledema).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Keith-Wagener-Barker Classification:

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient with a history of chronic arthritis on treatment came with complaints of defective vision in both eyes. On examination, vision in RE = 6/12, LE = 6/18, IOP = 18 mmHg in both eyes, and the anterior segment was normal. The fundus examination and fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) findings are shown in the figure. What is the probable diagnosis? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chloroquine toxicity

 

The patient's history of taking medication for rheumatoid arthritis and fundus with a bull's eye sign, along with the FFA image showing increased fluorescence in the macular area and round-shaped blocked fluorescence in the central fovea, suggest likely chloroquine toxicity. Here are some key points about chloroquine toxicity:

 

  • Prolonged administration of chloroquine may lead to a keratopathy, myopathy, retinopathy, and optic neuropathy.
  • Chloroquine retinopathy is a serous pigmentary degeneration of the retina that may result in vision loss.
  • A mild pigmentary disturbance in the macular area causes visual field defects, particularly a central scotoma, and a characteristic "bull's-eye" retinal lesion that can be seen on fluorescein angiography.
  • Eventually, there is a widespread retinal atrophy with pigment clumping and attenuated retinal vessels.
  • Short-term use of chloroquine can produce blurring of vision and diplopia, which is reversible upon stopping the drug.
  • Hydroxychloroquine has a lower risk of ocular toxicity than chloroquine, but it has a weaker anti-inflammatory effect.
  • The maximum dose allowed for chloroquine is 6 mg/kg in 24 hours, while for hydroxychloroquine, it is 4.5 mg/kg. Hydroxychloroquine is more commonly used today at a dose of 300-400 mg/day.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Choroiditis: This condition usually presents with patches of inflammation in the choroid, which are not observed in the provided images.

 

Option C. Steroid-induced glaucoma: This would more typically involve elevated intraocular pressure and optic nerve changes, which were not reported in the patient's examination.

 

Option D. Macular edema: While this might also involve changes in the macular region, it generally does not present with the specific "bull's eye" pattern seen in chloroquine toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Pupils react but do not accommodate
Pupils accommodate but do not react

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient came with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse around 20 years ago following which he had developed genital ulcers. Now, he complains of neurological symptoms and visual disturbances. Which of the following will be seen on exposure of his pupils to light? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pupils accommodate but do not react

 

  • The patient most likely contracted syphilis through unprotected sexual intercourse and later developed neurosyphilis as a consequence (neurological and visual disturbances).
  • Argyll-Robertson pupil, which is a condition characterized by intact accommodation reflex, but absent light reflex in the affected eye. (ARP-PRA)
  • Features of Argyll Robertson pupil (ARP) are bilateral small pupils with the following characteristics:
  1. Accommodation Reflex Present (ARP):  Pupillary constriction when looking at near objects.
  2. Light Reflex absent: Do not constrict when exposed to bright light (i.e., they do not react to light).
  • This is an example of light near dissociation.
  • Neurosyphilis is a manifestation of syphilis infection that affects the central nervous system, which occurs due to the invasion of the central nervous system by T. pallidum and can occur in any stage of syphilis.
  • Clinical features of neurosyphilis include:
    • Fleeting and repetitive lancinating pains, primarily in the legs.
    • Ataxia and gait disturbances due to loss of position sense.
    • Loss of reflexes in the legs.
    • Paraesthesia’s.
    • Bladder disturbances.
    • Acute abdominal pain with vomiting (visceral crisis).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pupils react but do not accommodate: This is not characteristic of any specific condition and does not describe Argyll Robertson pupil.

 

Option C. Pupils neither react nor accommodate: This indicates more widespread dysfunction of the pupillary muscles and is not specific for neurosyphilis.

 

Option D. Pupils react and accommodate: This describes normal pupillary function, which would not be expected in the context of the described symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Argyll Robertson pupil, characterized by pupils that accommodate but do not react to light, is a hallmark of neurosyphilis. This condition reflects damage to the central nervous system by Treponema pallidum, which affects both the neurological and visual systems.

questions.text: A patient presented with severe eye pain, redness, and thick purulent discharge. The symptoms started gradually over 2 days after swimming in a contaminated pool while wearing contact lenses. On examination, there is a central corneal infiltrate with satellite lesions and hypopyon. Which organism is the most likely causative agent? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pseudomonas aeruginosa

 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative bacterium commonly associated with contact lens-related keratitis, particularly after exposure to contaminated water. The infection is characterized by:

  • Rapid progression (24-48 hours)
  • Dense, central stromal infiltrate
  • Characteristic satellite lesions
  • Mucopurulent discharge
  • Hypopyon formation
  • Significant pain and inflammation

 

The risk factors include:

  • Contact lens wear
  • Exposure to contaminated water
  • Poor contact lens hygiene
  • Extended wear lenses

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acanthamoeba: While also associated with contact lens use and water exposure, Acanthamoeba typically presents with a ring-shaped infiltrate rather than a central infiltrate with satellite lesions. The pain is disproportionate to clinical findings, and progression is usually more gradual.

 

Option C. Staphylococcus aureus: Though it can cause keratitis, S. aureus typically presents with a smaller, discrete infiltrate and doesn't usually form satellite lesions. It's less commonly associated with swimming pool exposure.

 

 

Option D. Streptococcus pyogenes: Streptococcal keratitis is less common in contact lens wearers and typically presents with a more diffuse infiltrate without the characteristic satellite lesions seen in Pseudomonal infection.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Pseudomonas keratitis is a sight-threatening emergency characterized by rapid progression, central corneal infiltrate with satellite lesions, and hypopyon, commonly occurring in contact lens wearers exposed to contaminated water

choices.text: Relative afferent pupillary defect is seen.
There is no pain on ocular movement.
Multiple myeloma is a common cause.
Oral corticosteroids are the mainstay of treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about optic neuritis?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Relative afferent pupillary defect is seen.

 

In optic neuritis, a characteristic sign is the presence of a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) or Marcus Gunn pupil. This can be elicited by performing a swinging flashlight test, where a flashlight is moved between the normal and affected eye while observing the pupil response. Normally, both pupils remain constricted when light is shone on them. However, in the presence of RAPD, the pupil in the affected eye will dilate instead of constrict when the light is moved from the normal eye to the affected eye. This paradoxical response of the pupil to light is known as Marcus Gunn pupil, and is an important diagnostic finding in optic neuritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. There is no pain on ocular movement:

 

Pain With Eye Movement

 

  • Pain sensation worsening after movement of the eye ball is specific to typical ON. At the site of the apex, the optic nerve sheath is proximal to the superior and medial rectus. Consequently, when the patient moves the eye ball, contraction of the ocular muscles irritates the inflamed optic nerve sheath to cause the pain . It is less likely for patients with anterior ON to develop pain with eye movement, because the optic nerve sheath of the anterior nerve is not pulled by the ocular muscles.

 

Option C. Multiple myeloma is a common cause:

 

  • Isolated ON and MS-associated ON (MS-ON) are usually grouped together as typical ON, since they share concurrent characteristics, including age ranging from 18 to 50, unilaterality, pain with eye movement, rapid vision loss, and the tendency to reach the lowest level of visual acuity within two weeks of onset.

 

(Yang X, Li X, Lai M, Wang J, Tan S, Chan HH. Pain Symptoms in Optic Neuritis. Front Pain Res (Lausanne). 2022 Apr 14;3:865032. doi: 10.3389/fpain.2022.865032. PMID: 35498555; PMCID: PMC9046587)

 

  • Atypical ON, especially the neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder (NMOSD) associated ON (NMOSD-ON), is more commonly bilateral (around 20%) than MS-ON
  • For differentiated diagnosis, an oligoclonal band (OCB) is more frequently discovered in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) of MS patients (85%) than NMOSD patients (15-30%) . The presence of aquaporin protein 4 antibodies (AQP4-IgG), which are found in more than 90% of NMOSD-ON patients in conjunction with the clinical features, helps to diagnose NMOSD with high sensitivity (99%) and specificity (90%).
  • Due to its unique clinical characteristics, including dominance of male gender, a single attack, better recovery of visual acuity, presentation as ON at onset is usually in adults, but presentation as acute demyelinating encephalomyelitis (ADEM) at onset is mostly in children. MOG associated disorder (MOGAD) is increasingly considered as a disease entity distinct from NMOSD.
  • Clinically isolated syndrome (CIS) refers to that the patient underwent a single or multiple phases of neurologic symptoms that might progressed to MS but at that moment these symptoms cannot fulfill the diagnostic criteria of MS (Karussis, 2014).
  • Multiple myeloma is not a known cause of optic neuritis.

 

Option D. Oral corticosteroids are the mainstay of treatment:

 

  • Oral corticosteroid therapy alone is not recommended for optic neuritis.
  • Intravenous methylprednisolone may be used if radiological evidence of multiple sclerosis is present.
  • Oral corticosteroid therapy alone is associated with an increased risk of new attacks of optic neuritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A relative afferent pupillary defect is a critical clinical sign in diagnosing optic neuritis, highlighting the asymmetric impact on optic nerve function. Understanding and correctly identifying this sign is vital for early and accurate diagnosis and management of optic neuritis.

questions.text: In a patient presenting with recurrent chalazion, which cancer is suspected?(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sebaceous cell carcinoma

 

Explanation:

 

Sebaceous cell carcinoma is a malignancy of the sebaceous glands, which can present as recurrent chalazion.

 

Chalazion is an inflammation of the meibomian glands, which are modified sebaceous glands located in the eyelids.

 

While chalazion is typically a benign condition, its recurrence, particularly in elderly patients, can be indicative of underlying sebaceous cell carcinoma.

 

This carcinoma is notorious for masquerading as benign eyelid lesions, thus a history of recurrent chalazion warrants further investigation to rule out this malignancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Squamous cell carcinoma: This is the second most common type of eyelid cancer, but it does not typically present as recurrent chalazion. It more often presents as a chronic, non-healing ulcerative lesion.

 

Option C. Basal cell carcinoma: This is the most common eyelid cancer but usually presents as a pearly nodule with telangiectasia rather than as recurrent chalazion.

 

Option D. Kaposi’s sarcoma: This vascular tumor is associated with immunocompromised states such as HIV/AIDS. It typically presents as red or purple macules, plaques, or nodules, not as recurrent chalazion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recurrent chalazion should raise suspicion for sebaceous cell carcinoma, especially in elderly patients, as this malignancy can mimic benign eyelid lesions.

questions.text: A patient presents with vertical diplopia while walking downstairs. To correct that, he tilts the head on one shoulder. Which nerve palsy is suspected?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 4th CN palsy

 

Explanation:

 

The patient presenting with vertical diplopia while walking downstairs and tilting the head on one shoulder to correct the vision suggests a 4th cranial nerve (CN) palsy. The 4th cranial nerve, also known as the trochlear nerve, innervates the superior oblique muscle.

 

The primary actions of the superior oblique muscle include intorsion, depression, and abduction of the eye.

 

When there is a palsy of the 4th cranial nerve, the affected eye may have difficulty performing these movements, leading to vertical diplopia. Patients often adopt a compensatory head tilt to align the eyes properly and alleviate the double vision. The head tilt is typically towards the shoulder opposite the affected eye, compensating for the muscle's inability to properly intort and depress the eye.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3rd CN palsy: This palsy typically presents with ptosis (drooping eyelid) and an eye that is deviated down and out. Patients often lift their chin to see beneath the drooping lid, not to correct vertical diplopia.

 

Option C. 6th CN palsy: The 6th cranial nerve innervates the lateral rectus muscle, responsible for abduction of the eye. A palsy here would result in horizontal diplopia, not vertical diplopia, and the patient might turn their head to compensate, not tilt it.

 

Option D. 7th CN palsy: This nerve controls facial muscles, and its palsy leads to facial muscle weakness or paralysis, not issues related to eye movement or diplopia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

4th cranial nerve palsy (trochlear nerve palsy) leads to vertical diplopia, which patients often compensate for by tilting their head to the opposite shoulder to align the eyes and improve vision.

 

Mnemonic – SO4 LR6 and rest all by cranial nerve 3

 

Superior oblique by 4th CN; Lateral rectus by 6th CN and Rest all muscle by 3rd CN

questions.text: Most common cause of blindness in children is:(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin A deficiency

 

The correct answer is Vitamin A Deficiency. It remains the leading cause of preventable blindness in children due to its severe impact on the cornea and overall eye health when left untreated.

 

Vitamin A deficiency is a major cause of preventable blindness in children, particularly in developing countries. It can lead to xerophthalmia, a condition that can progress to night blindness and more severe damage to the cornea, potentially resulting in complete blindness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glaucoma: Childhood glaucoma is rare compared to other causes of visual impairment in children. When it does occur, it can lead to blindness if not treated. However, it is not the most common cause of blindness in children globally.

 

Option C. Cataract: Cataracts in children can be congenital or develop in childhood, leading to blindness if not treated. Pediatric cataract is a significant cause of visual impairment in children, but it is not as common as vitamin A deficiency in causing blindness.

 

Option D. Refractive Error: Refractive errors, such as myopia (nearsightedness), hyperopia (farsightedness), and astigmatism, are common in children. If left uncorrected, they can significantly impair vision but are not typically considered a direct cause of blindness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin A deficiency is the most common cause of preventable blindness in children in developing countries.

questions.text: Oculus Dexter refers to: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Right Eye

 

Explanation:

 

"Oculus Dexter" (OD) is a term used in ophthalmology to refer to the right eye. The terminology comes from Latin, where "Oculus" means "eye" and "Dexter" means "right." This is a common notation used in medical records and prescriptions related to eye care.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left Eye (Oculus Sinister): Referred to as "OS" in medical terminology.

 

Option C. Both Eyes (Oculus Uterque): Referred to as "OU" in medical terminology.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect as OD clearly refers to the right eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

"Oculus Dexter" (OD) refers to the right eye.
